newsitem.title: GREECE: Greek socialist PM claims election victory.
newsitem.headline: Greek socialist PM claims election victory.

text.p: Greece's socialist Prime Minister Costas Simitis, who gambled on early national elections, claimed a "great victory" on Sunday after winning a four-year term.

"The people showed they want a new course for Greece and society. This great victory belongs to all citizens who envision a better future," he said in a statement. "This victory belongs to all who believe in development coupled with social justice."
Socialist supporters poured out on to the streets of Athens to celebrate, sounding car horns, waving flags and setting off firerworks into the night sky.
Simitis, 60, succeeded in January his mentor, ailing socialist party founder and three-term prime minister Andreas Papandreou, who died in June.
With his fresh win and new free hand he is expected to name his cabinet by Tuesday and may change both his defence and foreign ministers.
Greek opposition leader Miltiades Evert, who ran a surprisingly close race, conceded defeat and said he was resigning as leader of the conservative New Democracy party.
"I take personal responsibility for the election result. I resign as president of the (conservative) party," he said in a brief televised statement.
Evert, 57, fought a vigorous campaign after Simitis called early elections and confounded pollsters by coming from behind to run a neck-and-neck race.
But early election returns showed the conservatives trailing by three percentage points and acting Interior Minister Vassilis Kouris said the socialist lead was irreversible.
Most embarrassing for Evert was that it appeared a solid block of conservatives had voted for Simitis.

With 15.6 percent of the vote counted, the socialists had 42.1 percent and the conservatives 39 percent. Electoral experts said that would give Simitis around 162 deputies in the 300-seat parliament, a solid absolute majority.
